facts.text: Appeal No. 1732 of 1967 filed in Supreme Court from Patna High Court judgment dated December 22, 1965 in Misc. Judicial Case No. 101 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civill Appeal No. 1732 of 1967. Appeal from the judgment and order dated December 22, 1965 of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Case No. 101 of 1962.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal referred question under s. 66 of Income-tax Act, 1922 to Patna High Court: whether Rs. 2,20,000 was income of assessee assessable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal from a judgment of the Patna High Court in a reference made to it under s. 66 1  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, by the Appellate Tribunal by which the following question of law was referred for determination by the High Court- Whether on the facts and circumstances of this case, the Tribunal was right in holding that the sum of Rs. 2,20,000/- was the income of the assessee assessable to tax under the provisions of the Income-tax Act ?

facts.text: Original assessee was Maharaja Partap Udainath Sah Deo, holder of an impartible estate.

anchor.surface_text: The original assessee was Maharaja Partap Udainath Sah Deo the holder 1 of an impartible estate.

facts.text: On January 22, 1944, assessee granted lease of mining rights to Aluminium Production Company Ltd. for 171-03 acres of land for 30 years.

anchor.surface_text: On January 22, 1944 the assesses granted a lease of certain mining rights to Aluminium Production Company Ltd. in respect of 171-03 acres of land for a period of 30 years.

facts.text: Lease terms: Salami inclusive of Moharkari and Dewani Negi Rs.5,000/- Rs. 2,25,000/-; Rent 8/- per acre; Royalty 6/- per ton; Minimum royalty Rs. 22/- per acre.

anchor.surface_text: The main terms were as follows Salami  inclusive of Moharkari and Dewani Negi amounting to Rs.5,000/- Rs. 2,25,000/- Rent /8/- per acre Royalty /6/- per ton.  iV  Minimum royalty Rs. 22/- per acre.

facts.text: Previously, assessee granted prospecting lease of 311 acres to same Company on March 20, 1941 for one year.

anchor.surface_text: Previously the assessee had granted a prospecting lease of 311 acres of land to the same Company on March 20, 1941 fox a period of one year.

facts.text: 1941 lease terms: salami Rs. 100/- per acre; royalty /8/- annas per ton.

anchor.surface_text: The area companyered by that lease though larger included substantially the area leased out subsequently. The terms of the 1941-lease were that salami was payable at the rate of Rs. 100/- per acre and royalty at the rate of /8/- annas per ton.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer for 1944-45 treated Rs. 2,20,000 of salami as advance payment of royalty and as income; Rs. 5,000 as Dewani Negi and Moharkari.

anchor.surface_text: While making the assessment for the year 1944-45 the Income- tax Officer took the view that the assessee had chosen to take large sum by way of salami white granting the lease in the year 1944 and had accepted lesser rate of royalty, the salami represented an advance payment of royalty. He treated Rs. 5,000 out of the sum of Rs. 2,25,000 as Dewani Negi and Moharkari and the balance of Rs. 2,20,000 was treated by him as income of the assessee, and the assessment was made accordingly.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held Rs. 2,20,000 as salami, capital receipt not taxable.

anchor.surface_text: on appeal the Appellate Assistant Commissioner held that the amount of Rs. 2,20,000 was paid by the Company to the assessee as salami and as such it was a capital receipt and number taxable.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal on August 7, 1952 remanded case to Appellate Assistant Commissioner to find if salami was income.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the Revenue the Appellate Tribunal by an order dated August 7, 1952 remanded the case to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner for finding whether there were circumstances to indicate that the salami was really receipt of income.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner report dated April 12, 1956: assessee accepted lower royalty intentionally, Rs. 2,20,000 major portion advance royalty.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner made a report dated April 12, 1956. He gave a finding that the assessee had intentionally accepted lower. royalty and taken higher salami and therefore the major portion of the sum of Rs. 2,20,000 had been taken in exchange of royalty that would have accrued during the period-of lease.

facts.text: Tribunal order dated July 26, 1956 allowed Revenue appeal, restored ITO order.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal by an order dated July-26, 1956 allowed the appeal of the Revenue and restored the order of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Patna High Court held Rs. 20,000 of Rs. 2,20,000 as capital salami not taxable, remaining Rs. 2,00,000 as revenue receipt taxable.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that out of the sum of Rs. 2,20, 000 the amount which companyld be regarded to be salami and treated as a capi- tal receipt companyld reasonably be estimated at a sum Rs. 20,000 which was number assessable to tax but the remaining amount of Rs. 2, 00,000 was revenue receipt and was taxable as such.

facts.text: High Court reframed referred question and answered partly in favour of assessee but substantially for Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: The question referred was reframed as follows- Whether on the facts and the circumstances of this case the Tribunal was right in holding that the sum of Rs. 2,20,000 or any portion thereof was the income of the assessee assess- able to tax under the provisions of the Income-tax Act ? It was answered partly in favour of the assessee but substantially in favour of the Revenue.

facts.text: Tribunal based decision on difference in salami and royalty rates between 1941 prospecting lease and 1944 lease.

anchor.surface_text: Now the Appellate Tribunal appears to have based its decision only on the difference between the amount of salami and the rate of royalty between the prospecting lease which was granted in 1941 and the subsequent lease of 1944.

facts.text: 1941 lease covered 311 acres including substantially the 171 acres of 1944 lease; about 140 acres overlap.

anchor.surface_text: This is what the Tribunal stated in para 7 of its order- In 1941, the assessee had granted a prospecting lease in favour of the very lessee taking a much smaller premium fixing the royalty at /8/- per ton. ... out of the area of 171 acres that was companyered by the later lease a substantial portion of it about 140 acres were companyprised in the area leased out by the earlier deed of 1941.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Tribunal's comparison of 1941 prospecting lease (1 year) and 1944 lease (30 years) not reasonable basis.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to appreciate how a companyparison of the terms of the lease of 1941 which was only for one year and which was for a different purpose, namely, prospecting companyld afford a reasonable basis for determining whether the terms of the 1944 lease were fixed in such manner that part of the proceeds of royalty were included in the figure of the salami.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside High Court order, answered question in favour of assessee against Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above the appeal is allowed and the order of the High Court is set aside. The answer to the question referred is returned in favour of the assessee and against the Revenue.

facts.text: Assessee granted other leases in 1933, 1938, 1945 with royalty 8-12 annas per ton, salami Rs.100-130 per acre.

anchor.surface_text: The terms of the leases on which the High Court relied related to the years 1933, 1938 and 1945, the rate of royalty varied from 8 annas to 12 annas per ton and that of salami from Rs. 100 to Rs. 130 per acre.

facts.text: Mines Superintendent report dated January 7, 1956: area leased in 1944 contained commercial grade Bauxite approx 13 lakh tons.

anchor.surface_text: An.other factor that was relied upon was the report of the Mines Superintendent dated January 7, 1956 according to whom the area leased out in 1944 companytained companymercial grade Bauxite of approximately 13 lakh tons.

facts.text: High Court estimated salami at Rs.20,000 based on other leases rate of Rs.100 per acre.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court proceeded to assess the salami at Rs. 20,000 on the basis that for the other leases the rate agreed upon was Rs. 100 per acre.

facts.text: Supreme Court held onus on Revenue to show salami was income; no sufficient material.

anchor.surface_text: The onus, however, is upon the income tax authorities to show that there exist facts and circumstances which would make payment of what has been called salami, income.

That general right may properly be regarded as a capital asset and the money paid to purchase it may properly be held to be a payment on capital account. But merely because a certain amount paid

concepts.unlisted_description: Lump sum payment in lease for mining rights

anchor.surface_text: The principles on which the courts have acted whenever a question has arisen whether a payment described as a salami is capital or revenue receipt are well settled. Salami is a single payment made for the acquisition of the right of the lessor by-the lessee to enjoy the benefits granted to him by the lease. That general right may properly be regarded as a capital asset and the money paid to purchase it may properly be held to be a payment on capital account. But merely because a certain amount paid to the lessor is termed as salami it does number follow that numberinquiry can be made to determine whether it has or has number an element of revenue receipt in the shape of advance payment of royalty or rent. The onus, however, is upon the income tax authorities to show that there exist facts and circumstances which would make payment of what has been called salami, income. The position may be summed up in this way. When the interest of the lessor is parted for a price the price paid is premium or salami but the periodical payments made for the company- tinuous enjoyment of the benefits under the lease are in the nature of rent the former is a capital receipt and the latter a revenue receipt.

concepts.interpretation: Salami/premium capital if for parting interest in land; revenue if advance rent/royalty; depends on facts

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ount of Rs. 2,20,000 was paid by the Company to the assessee as salami and as such it was a capital receipt and number taxable. On appeal by the Reven

When the interest of the lessor is parted for a price the price paid is premium or salami but the periodical payments made for the company- tinuous enjoyment of the benefits under the lease are in the nature of rent the former is a capital receipt and the latter a revenue receipt.

anchor.surface_text: Parties may camouflage the real nature of the transaction by using clever phraseology and, therefore, it is number the form but the circumstances of the transaction that matter. The numberenclature used may number be decisive or companyclusive but it helps the companyrts, having regard to the other circumstances, to ascertain the intention of the parties.  See Commissioner of Income-tax, Assam etc., v. The Panbari Tea Co. Ltd.  1 .  1  1965 3 S.C.R. 811.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above the appeal is allowed and the order of the High Court is set aside. The answer to the question referred is returned in favour of the assessee and against the Revenue.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Revenue failed to discharge onus with sufficient facts/circumstances; lower courts relied on unreasonable lease comparisons and arbitrary estimations without material details.

holdings.text: Salami is a single payment made for the acquisition of the right of the lessor by the lessee to enjoy the benefits granted to him by the lease and is prima facie a capital receipt.

anchor.surface_text: The principles on which the courts have acted whenever a question has arisen whether a payment described as a salami is capital or revenue receipt are well settled. Salami is a single payment made for the acquisition of the right of the lessor by-the lessee to enjoy the benefits granted to him by the lease.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restatement of well-settled principles applied to facts; distinguished from revenue if proven as advance royalty/rent.

holdings.text: The onus is upon the income tax authorities to show that there exist facts and circumstances which would make payment of what has been called salami, income.

anchor.surface_text: The onus, however, is upon the income tax authorities to show that there exist facts and circumstances which would make payment of what has been called salami, income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Burden shifts to Revenue once labeled salami; assessee need not disprove absent Revenue's prima facie case.

holdings.text: A comparison of the terms of the 1941 prospecting lease (one year) with the 1944 mining lease (30 years) does not afford a reasonable basis for holding salami includes royalty.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to appreciate how a comparison of the terms of the lease of 1941 which was only for one year and which was for a different purpose, namely, prospecting could afford a reasonable basis for determining whether the terms of the 1944 lease were fixed in such manner that part of the proceeds of royalty were included in the figure of the salami.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Different purposes/durations justify higher salami/lower royalty in long-term lease; Tribunal erred in relying solely thereon.

holdings.text: Mere fact of substantial salami amount does not justify treating it as capitalised royalty without more.

anchor.surface_text: It must not be forgotten that the mere fact that the amount taken on account of salami was substantial and on the face it looked considerably large would not justify the view that that amount represented capitalised royalty.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Size alone insufficient; requires circumstances showing camouflage as advance royalty.

holdings.text: No material placed to disbelieve lease description of amount as salami/premium, similar to Panbari Tea Co. case.

anchor.surface_text: The position does not seem to be different in the present case. A good deal of emphasis has been laid on behalf of the Revenue on the statement in the order of the Tribunal towards the conclusion that it was in entire agreement with the Income-tax Officers order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogy to Panbari: absent direct/circumstantial evidence of camouflage, accept document nomenclature.

holdings.text: Onus on Revenue to show salami was camouflaged royalty; assessee not required to explain differences absent Revenue discharging onus first.

anchor.surface_text: This approach cannot be regarded as correct. The onus was on the Revenue to show what was stipulated in the indenture of lease as a payment by way of salami was some other kind of payment, namely, royalty, camouflaged as salami.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in shifting burden to assessee; Revenue must lead with evidence.

holdings.text: High Court's estimation of salami at Rs. 20,000 based on other leases' rates is arbitrary and insufficient to discharge onus.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to concur in this method of computing the amount of the salami. Much more, material was required for discharging the onus which lay on the Revenue to show that the assessee was bound to, charge only the same amount of salami which had been taken for the other leases about which the details of the quantity of minerals which could, be extracted from the area covered by them were altogether lacking.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lacked details on minerals/reserves in other leases; no examination of assessee.

holdings.text: Mines Superintendent's post-lease report on reserves irrelevant as assessee unaware at time of granting lease.

anchor.surface_text: Moreover the High Court lost sight of the fact that the report of the Mines Superintendent was made long after the date of the 1944 lease and it could not be assumed that at the time of the granting of that lease the assessee knew how much quantity of the mineral could be extracted from the area which had been leased out.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Report dated 1956 cannot retroactively impute knowledge to 1944 parties.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Assam etc. v. The Panbari Tea Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Principles on which courts have acted to determine whether payment described as salami is capital or revenue receipt: salami is single payment for acquisition of lease rights (capital), but inquiry possible if element of advance royalty/rent; onus on income tax authorities; substance over form and nomenclature.
precedents.cited_holding: Where lease described salami/premium as such with no material (direct or circumstantial) to disbelieve and hold it rent, it is capital receipt; declined to assume camouflage.

The principles on which the courts have acted whenever a question has arisen whether a payment described as a salami is capital or revenue receipt are well settled. Salami is a single payment made for the acquisition of the right of the lessor by-the lessee to enjoy the benefits granted to him by the lease.
